The report of a Committee shall be presented by the Chairman or inhis absence by any other member of the Committee authorized by theChairman.
, he has to be authorized bythe Chairman. So, how can I present it to the Parliament ? Icannot present it.

, . , , Whereuon MR. SPEAKER left the Chair and THE HON. DIMUTHUBANDARA ABAYAKOON took the Chair.

Hon. Prime Minister, I would like to bring one incident foryour kind consideration. On the 26th of April, five Tamilyouths were gruesomely murdered and dumped in theAvissawella area. At the All Party Conference we brought upthis matter and the Inspector General of Police told us thatthere will be an impartial investigation and the outcomewill be let known to the nation. To date nothing has happened.

Mr. Mahalingam from Wattala, the father of one of themurdered youths, telephoned me a little while ago. He hasidentified his sons body, who had been grusesomelymurdered on the 26th of April. He wants to have the funeralon the coming Saturday, the 8th and the body is still at theKalubowila Hospital. He made a request: he asked me totelephone the Avissawella Police and request their assistanceto get this body released as early as possible so that he canhave the furneral at 3.00 p.m. at the Wattala crematorium.There five youths were beheaded. I think, Hon. PrimeMinister, you are well aware of this. I would kindly urge youin this House, in this aughst Assembly, to give assistance toMr. Mahalingam and see that every help is given to him totake his sons body to Wattala. The Government should bearthe expenses, I urge you, Hon Prime Minister, as a gesture of

goodwill as it always says that it is concerned about all thecitizens of this country. You must do something about it. Iwould kindly urge you to instruct the Officer-In-Charge ofthe Avissawella Police to extend all his assistance to Mr.Mahalingam, who is the father of Mahendra Kumar,commonly known as Sana, who was gruesomely murdered.Also I would request you to go into this matter and let usknow what has happened. All the five youths were Tamils.They were beheaded. + , + + , + ?
The Government has failed to protect its citizens in spiteof having the Emergency Regulations in force. So, what isthe use of this Emergency?

The day before yesterday, the Hon. MahindaSamarasinghe had a press conference and suggested, someguidelines to the police officers and the defence authoritiesto be followed when arresting a person. But in Hatton, I hearone body has been arrested and his father is unable to knowhis whereabouts. Only the day before yesterday theseguidelines were announced and today they are not beingfollowed. We are not able to trece the people who are beingarrested. So, this is the way things are happening. I wouldurge the Hon. Prime Minister to look into these incidentsand see that the police do their duty according to theguidelines given by you. + + ? [ , { + , + ? ; ; ; ? ? , +
. . ( )( - , )(The Hon. S. M. Chandrasena - Minister of Agrarian Services

Mr. Presiding Member, before I deal with the EmergencyDebate on which the vote is to be taken at the end of theday, since the Hon. deputy Minister of Justice is here, Ithought I will clarify briefly the SLMCs position on theEighteenth Amendment. I do not know whether you are
taking the vote on the Eighteenth Amendment today. -[Interruption] Anyway, whatever it may be, it is incumbenton the SLMC to clarify its position.

An impression has been created that the SLMC was theparty blocking the passage of this Bill infact the SLMCsposition was that since the powers of the court of Appealare to be taken to the provinces, the working of the Courtof Appeal in the provinces will enable litigants in thoseareas to transact matters regarding their litigation in thosecourts. We expected certain other jurisdictions, originaljurisdiction vested in the Supreme Court also to be broughtto the Court of Appeal level. But the Hon. Minister of Justicepointed out that this cluster of subjects could be dealt within a separate legislation and that it was not possible for themto concede those amendments. But however, at the last PartyLeaders Meeting when the Chief Government Whipinquired from me as to whether we are still keen about theposition that we have taken in the past, I indicated to himthat we do not want to stand in the way of the passage ofthis Bill since the lawyers from Hulftsdorp, various judgesand everybody else appear to think that the Bill needs togo through if cases are to be expedited and that it will alsoenable about 11 more Court of Appeal Judges to beappointed. So in deference to that request we conceded thatwe will support this Bill. So the SLMC will, if the Bill istaken up today, give its wholehearted support.

In the meantime, it is very unfortunate that the mainOpposition has taken up a position not to support the Billtoday and has tied it up with the issue concerning theConstitutional Council. But we expect that some kind ofdiscussion should take place between the two major partiesand this matter be resolved, so that we can give effect tothe Eighteenth Amendment to enable the Court of Appealto function in the Provinces.

We only have one particular concern and that is thefunctioning of the Court of Appeal in the North EastProvince. The purpose of the Amendment is to make it easierfor litigants to transact their business. As it is they have tocome to Colombo to pursue their cases in the Court ofAppeal. Now if the sitting of the Court of Appeal is to bein Trincomalee for people in Ampara and various otherplaces it might make it more difficult. - [Interruption.]
( )( - , , )(The Hon. Dilan Perera - Deputy Minister of Justice and Law

Reforms and Deputy Minister of Constitutional Affairs andNational Integration)It will not happen that way because after 11 more judgesare appointed we will not have it in Trincomalee only.The President of the Court of Appeal will get the judges
to go on circuit various places in the North East Province,not only to Trincomalee on circuit like what the formerCommissioners of Assize did.

( [ )(The Hon. Rauff Hakeem)Thank you very much. If that is the decision, then wewill apppreciate it. So I think I have made my position veryclear on the Eighteenth Amendment, and I only hope thatthere would be a better understanding on this issue and thatwe would be able to give effect to this Amendment as earlyas possible. - [Interruption.]

( )(The Hon. Dilan Perera)Can I make one request from you? Now it seems that all partiesare in total agreement with the Eighteenth Amendment. If you canmake use of your good offices and relationship with the -

( [ )(The Hon. Rauff Hakeem)In fact, I took it up with the Leader of the Oppositionyesterday. I told him the background to the issue and thathis own Chief Whip conceded this matter at the PartyLeaders Meeting and that it is nothing but proper for us tosupport it. But unfortunately I did not succeed.
( )(The Hon. Dilan Perera)It seems that it is only the UNP that is blocking it rightnow.
( [ )(The Hon. Rauff Hakeem)It seems so. I just want my party to be exonerated fromthe accusation. I am no more -

( )(The Hon. (Dr.) Rajitha Senaratne)Hon. Deputy Minister, we are supporting the EighteenthAmendment. Even I have spoken in Parliament in support ofthis legislation. The only problem is about itsimplementation. What we say is, first form the ConstitutionalCouncil. Let the Constitutional Council, an independentbody, make the appointments. Otherwise, what will happenis, it will again go to the political authority to the President.
( )(The Hon. Dilan Perera)Hon. Member, if I may explain to you, now that we are intotal agreement with the Eighteenth Amendment, what wecan do is, we can get together and pass the Eighteenth

[ ]Amendment, Of course there have been talks even at theParty Leaders Meeting, among all parities on how we aregoing face the problems in implementing some of the issuesthat have arisen out of the Seventeenth Amendment. But, ifyou keep on trying to tie up the Seventeenth Amendment tothe Eighteenth Amendment, then the Eighteenth Amendmentwill never go through.
( [ )(The Hon. Rauff Hakeem)Mr. Deputy Minister my time is being taken up by thecross talks.
( [ )(The Hon. Rauff Hakeem)This matter can be settled between the Government andthe Opposition on a different day. In the meantime, , .

Mahinda invites LTTE to help evolve a peaceful solution

NEW DELHI, July 4: President Mahinda Rajapakse, has said hewants the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) to activelyparticipate in the efforts to evolve a lasting peaceful solution to theislands festering ethnic problem.In an interview to Indian television news channel NDTV broadcasttoday, he said he wants to submit a set of draft proposals for discussionwith the Tigers. The tigers should consider them, respond to them andcome up with their own suggestions and amendments.
The idea is to evolve a solution that will be acceptable to allcommunities inhabiting the island.
Rajapakse pointed out that he does not want to put forth any take-it-or-leave-it kind of proposals and force the Tigers to accept them.
He does not want to push them into a corner or make things difficultfor them either.

The President said both LTTE Chief velupillai Prabhakaran and heare Sri Lankans. So, we can sit and discuss this. I am saying to them:Come, discuss and tell us what you want. What I want is for him(Prabhakaran) to come and participate in the whole process.
Such deliberations can help the government put together ideas andproposals and produce a solution that is acceptable to all Sri Lankans.
. . . . . . . . . , . . , . . .In the Daily Mirror Newspaper of 3rdJuly 2006, he says I quote:
The APC as it is today is totally irrelevant to the purposeexpected to be gained.
The question is what would a large majority of the Tamilpeople want and not the LTTE.
Not the LTTE, but what the majority of the Tamil people want.
These suggestions come up when you dont address the prob-lem properly I dont think confederation is what the vastmajority of the Tamil people want What they seek is one thatis more Federal in nature.
Any solution that is unitary will not be accepted by the Tamilpeople.
The President will have to give a federal solution It is asolution that is even federal in nature that will be accepted.
Those who clamour for a de-merger of the North and theeast need to understand that any solution that attempts thatwill also be rejected.
There cant be an issue there. The quality of devolution is whatwill be important.
, ." " Whereupon THE HON. DIMUTHU BANDARA ABAYAKOONleft the Chair and MR. DEPUTY SPEAKER took the Chair.
, . . , Challenge of counter in-surgency warfare . Centre forStrategic and International Studies Strategic Analyst. . , I quote :
The key battle is always political and ideological at every levelfrom the local to the international No military victory possible withoutpolitical victory.
You cannot win where you do not go and stay.
The spirit and other moral qualities which animate an army are aGeneral or Government, public opinion in the province in which a waris raging.
